statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Nick Van Exel scored 33 points and James Posey hit two free throws with 3.6 seconds left after Van Exel missed a pair as Denver ended a four-game losing streak with a 93-90 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night.

related.description: Philadelphia 76ers coach Larry Brown was not on the bench Friday for the team's game with the Denver Nuggets.
related.linkText: Muscle spasms keep Sixers' Brown from sidelines
related.title: Brown unable to coach Friday due to back problem
related.headline: Brown unable to coach Friday due to back problem

article.headline: Van Exel delivers as Nuggets end four-game slide
article.linkText: Nuggets end losing streak despite Iverson's 38
article.story:
DENVER (AP) -- Nick Van Exel wouldn't gauge his matchup with Allen Iverson based solely on individual statistics. The Denver Nuggets guard based his evaluation on the final score. Van Exel scored 33 points and James Posey hit two free throws with 3.6 seconds left after Van Exel missed a pair as Denver ended a four-game losing streak with a 93-90 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night. "You can't make a judgment on stats alone because he's going to get a lot done with all his talent," Van Exel said. "The only way I can judge myself is by the final score." Iverson, the NBA's leading scorer, scored 38 points, shooting 14-for-29 and scoring 14 in the final quarter. Dikembe Mutombo added 13 points and 13 rebounds for the Sixers, who were without coach Larry Brown. Assistant coach Randy Ayers subbed for Brown after the coach complained of muscle spasms in his right shoulder and neck and never came out of the locker room. Iverson, who rarely drew Van Exel as a defensive assignment, preferred to critique his own teammates in the loss. "We were terrible out there, simple as that," Iverson said. "We couldn't stop anybody on defense and we had no chemistry on offense. I can't even see a game plan that we came in with on the offensive end. "They came up with some nice effort plays," Ayers said. "You combine that with Van Exel having 30-plus points and I think that was our downfall." Van Exel also had 11 assists. Posey and Voshon Lenard had 12 points each as the Nuggets avoided their second five-game losing streak of the year. Iverson's two free throws and a free throw by Raja Bell with 56 seconds left pulled Philadelphia to 91-90. Posey missed a 3-pointer, but with Iverson unable to free himself, Aaron McKie's 3-pointer fell short with 14 seconds left. Van Exel missed both free throws with 7.2 seconds left, but Posey converted two foul shots after Raef LaFrentz grabbed the offensive rebound. McKie's desperate shot at the buzzer missed the rim. "Posey and LaFrentz really bailed me out," Van Exel said. "And then we made a good defensive stand." Trailing 77-69 after three quarters, Iverson brought Philadelphia back with nine points, hitting a free throw off a defensive technical with 7:54 left to tie the game at 81-81. Derrick Coleman tied the game for the last time, 85-85 with 4:46 to go, and after LaFrentz tipped in a miss by Ryan Bowen, Van Exel hit two shots between a layup by Eric Snow as the Nuggets led 91-87. The Sixers trailed 57-54 early in the second half after two jump shots by Matt Harpring, but Van Exel's five points helped Denver maintain at least a six-point lead through the quarter. The Nuggets led 77-67 after three quarters on Ryan Bowen's tip and a 3-pointer from halfcourt by Van Exel that beat the buzzer. Lenard hit three jumpers in a 10-2 run to start the second quarter as the Nuggets took a 33-28 lead. Lenard was 5-for-5 in the quarter, and with Iverson 2-for-8, Philadelphia trailed 50-46 at the half. Iverson got off to a slow start, missing five of his first seven shots. "Nick was Nick, and any time Nick has the hot hand, you have a chance to win," Denver coach Mike Evans said. "I guess we did a nice job on Iverson by holding him under 40 points."

Game notes
Prior to the game the 76ers activated guard Speedy Claxton from the injured list and waived forward Michael Ruffin. ... Philadelphia is at full strength for the first time this year. ... During a Thursday practice, Antonio McDyess had his first dunk since Oct. 12 surgery on his left knee. ... Scott Williams played with a sprained right knee. ... Denver blocked a season-high 11 shots.
